The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is a measure of the average change over time in the prices paid by urban consumers for a market basket of consumer goods and services. When the CPI goes from 120 to 150, it means that prices have increased.

To find the percentage increase, you can use the formula:
(New CPI - Old CPI) / |Old CPI| \* 100%

Plugging in the values, we get:
(150 - 120) / |120| \* 100% = 30%

Therefore, prices have risen 30 percent.
